Interesting your coworkers did not understand how the latch magnet worked. I figured it out almost instantly just by seeing the magnets with that magnetic viewing film on it. When it is turned to a certain spot, the north and the south poles are lined up, thus they repulse each other and you get the "spring" action. When you rotate it, eventually the north will line up with south and they will all attract to each other and thus latch.

To be fair, I did have the explanation they gave to you. Which with that knowledge it is pretty common sense to me. I doubt your coworkers had that at the time.

I love your series, and I have a request.

One of the most mind- bending facts about magnets is that the magnetic field is not attached to the magnet. Meaning that rotating the magnet around its symmetry axis does not rotate the field.

This can be demonstrated by separating two closely spaced disk magnets with a piece of paper, or cardboard, or glass, then rotating one of them. If the field is pinned to the magnet, the other one should also rotate. But it doesn't.

I did my own experiment to verify this. You could show this with much better visualizations than I could, and reach a much wider audience. I used two neodymium disk magnets, separated by a layer of cardboard, and spun one of them with an electric drill, while the magnetically connected one remained stationary.

Those look like ceramic magnets. I, like your parents, work in an automotive fabrication plant and we have those at least it looks like exact same magnets, all over the place.
And i like you, have played with them, and also used them extensively at work.
And please be careful with those and other "hard" magnets.
Even when they arent that "strong", especially when they are in a stack, can slap together with a surprising ammount of force, and due to the brittleness of the material its made from, pretty forcefully shatter and send out sharp pieces of magnet. When you were tossing one magnet onto the stack of other magnets in front of and rather near your face, i was a lttle worried for you. Not trying to be a worry wart here, but ive had more than one magnet shatter on me and the pieces are pretty sharp and they can travel a decent distance.
Think of them kinda like shards of metallic glass.
Eye pro when playing with magnets. Might seem like a small deal but if a piece of magnet pireces your eye, it wont.
Stay safe.

This is nothing new... and you are touching something that essentially has one of them in it right now that works using the same exact principals...the memory card in your phone or computer... except it's done on a microscopic level...that is also how the black strip on a credit card works... this is why they tell you not to put your memory card or credit card near strong magnets...the strong magnet will flip the field lines so the sides are back to only north and south on each card... computers use binary code (1 or 0) or  on and off...or north or south like in this case...it's all the same exact thing... because of the very high amount of charged particles in something very small is why u can have things like sd cards so small that can contain vast amounts of information...this is nothing more than a scaled up version of a memory card which have been around for quite a while...

This "MAXELS" can also be found on a hard drive discs (HDD) of computers (not SSD). They save data in a very similar way this "maxel printer" works. If you look at 8:05 you can see red and blue dots on a disc. Example: On a HDD red is binary state 1 and blue is binary state 0. So when the "disc analyser" arm of HDD moves to a certain point on a disc/certain dot it reads the state. Combining this dots into a combination you get data. :)

Potential medical application ( sorry if this is already somewhere already in the 9000 comments I'm not gonna read): a Coulter Counter counts blood cells by a change in electrical signal. Where there is a changing electrical signal there is a magnetic field that can respond to an externally applied magnetic field. Similar electrical field changes may be occurring at capillary level blood vessel junctions and thus a microscopic magnetic field of north and south chain magnets, much like Garrett's assembly, could be used to promote blood flow, which, absent internal bleeding, is a useful aid to the body's own healing and regenerative processes. Applications could be in sports medicine, battlefield technology, shoe sole inserts, and insulated glove inserts; where improved circulation is needed. since the field to move a blood cell is not large , it may be possible to encode the field design into magnet-impregnated polymer sheets for flexibility or into mylar tape for use as a limb wrap. A USPTO search would be instructive.

i agree the push-pull locking spring is a huge game-changer. Here's a list of potential applications:

1. Dishwasher closure and locking (substitute pretty much any closure device of any kind from purses to drawers to the top button above the zipper on one's pants).
2. Flip the magnetic coupling 90 degrees, rotated around the axis, and you have a magnetically locked but never-touching torsional power transmission shaft.
3. Extension and retraction for an ink pen - provides nice magnetic cushion in extended mode!
4. Self-aligning Docking Ring for spacecraft. In this implementation, perhaps six to dozens are used, located around the docking ring, and linked by a large gear that turns them simultaneously. In the first position, they're attracted, but there's no bump due to the spring effect. Then, when they're all rotated, they attract and tightly align the docking rings. Subsequent mechanical clamps finish the job due to the pressure and large forces involved.

I'm surprised you thought this was new tech. Magnets are old tech. It is though a perfect example of markets controlling tech (or slowing innovation) to benefit their bottom line. These magnetic fields have been used primarily up to this point for data storage/reading (e.g. hard drives, credit card strips, etc.). But companies (e.g. Apple) that hold back or stalemate innovation so they can make their $$ before the rest of the world gets clean access to the tech to find other uses. That always isn't the case though. Sometimes it's literally the general public isn't educated enough to except some tech (e.g. NFC) until decades later. That's why I think what you do teaching the world one day at a time is so crucial and awesome. It truly can make most people Smarter Every Day.

Field Gradient Technology Field Gradient Technology uses bipolar magnets either singly or in a multiple-magnet array. The arrays are precisely spaced to produce a pattern of magnetic flow (flux lines) between the magnets, creating a complex field gradient of magnetic energy utilising multiple polarities and flux. EQL magnetic Technology Equilateral Magnetic Technology uses a patented design that increases the magnetic surface activity through a hexagonal array of equilateral triangles, each an alternating north or south pole magnet. This multiplies the number of positive and negative poles, thus creating more lines of magnetic flux. In turn, this maximises the magnetic and geometric complexity for a static field on a flat surface, so that the positioning of the surface is relevant to the object against which it is positioned and creates a uniform magnetic design from edge to edge.
Dynamic Magnetic Technology. A dynamic magnetic field is more complex than a static field and our massage products use this technology to create a deeply penetrating three-dimensional moving magnetic field. Magnetic Tension Technologies. Nikken’s latest technical developments are the patented Magnetic Tension Technologies, which start to bring some of the 3-dimensional complexity of the Dynamic Technology into a static form and come in three different configurations:
• RAM™ (Radial-Axis Magnetism) Technology modules feature circular clusters of six small magnetic spheres, with each positive-negative axis rotated 60 degrees relative to its neighbour in a stepped alignment that produce a series of overlapping magnetic fields in tension.
• SpyderRAM™ modules use the same magnetic arrangement but at a larger scale for use in a larger context such as KenkoSeats.
• DynaFlux® Technology positions magnetic surfaces with the same polar orientation, either positive or negative, opposite each other at multiple points. Interlocking construction holds these components in place, overcoming the repulsion generated by this arrangement, and specially designed magnets prevent demagnetisation which would otherwise occur. Placing separate magnetic fields in opposition produces a multiplier effect, increasing the magnetic strength and the depth of the field, taking magnetic complexity in a static device almost to dynamic levels

I wonder what the lifetime of these magnets are compared to normal magnets.

Eventually the electron lattices degrade, and I suspect that degradation occurs faster when you've got the magnetic lattices sitting next to each other constantly. With this technology, you could engineer a nearly lossless magnetic bearing and potentially build a spinning mag-lev shaft WITHOUT the need for a single point of physical contact to maintain stability on the unstable plane. In other words... something useful that actually floats and whose only point of energy loss would be air drag (like those spinning tops that float mid-air, but that can be driven by a power-capture source like a windmill).

It could make power generation much more efficient by creating focused fields that would travel through the Copper or Silver coils.

If they printed a breadboard style of magnet comprised of neutral points, then you could create a magnetic pole by passing electric current through it. If you were to be able to control this and get a high enough resolution, then you could dynamically change the shape of the maxels. So instead of a "Smarter every day" logo, you change the maxel configuration to another shape like a spiral. Add a computer controller, and you could dynamically change the shape ON THE FLY in a working machine (like a generator, or an electric motor)

You could also make an electric generator with it.
You first could make a big round magnet with 2 kinds of magnetic patterns (repeatly on it's circunference), and then make a lot of smaller round magnets with just one kind of magnetic pattern.
The smaller magnets would have coils around them and a round bar in their middle.

The first kind of magnetic pattern of the big magnet would repulse a smaller magnet, and the second pattern would attract a smaller magnet from afar, but repulse from up close. (you could have another big round magnet on the other side wich only repels the smaller magnets from a close distance).

Then you would rotate the big round magnet, and make the smaller magnets move and generate energy. (though I do'nt know about it's energy eficiency).

You could also organize the smaller magnets and magnetic patterns so that the net torque and force on the big magnet becomes close to zero and prevent it from wearing down. And you could put the smaller magnets in vacuum chambers to maximize the eficiency.
I think it can be utilized in any field where there is a loss of efficiency with the effect of "friction" acting as a necessary evil entity.

So if you have for example a workpiece that needs turning on both sides with two different programs. Then you can start machining one side and place maxels on the workpiece. But the other side needs to be the machined on the exact same spot on the Z and X axis. With traditional machining method you need to place a destructive flange on both the workpiece and chuck. Now you can have non-destructive flange on the workpiece to ensure it is fastened on the same spot on the C axis on the chuck.

I also always found magnets fascinating. When I was a teenager, I obtained a powerful metallic magnet, the shape of a small hotdog; it's called a "cow magnet", and hey actually feed them to cows, who swallow them whole. Any nails or metal debris they swallowed can get stuck in their intestines (it happens) and causes injury. The pieces stick to the magnet and are passed out the other end with it (must be fun retrieving it later on!). I had the most fun throwing it at the lockers and seeing which way it would roll (I also found out the hard way that a magnet will damage a CRT computer screen...sorry, teacher!)

I actually didn't know about the magnets in steering pumps (the shame!), but it stands to reason; oil drain plugs in the oil pan of engines also are magnetic, for the same reason. Every time you start an engine cold, a little bit of metal is worn off, and you don't want those little shavings running though the engine in the oil, wearing things out even more. They also let you know if there is a more serious problem; if you find small chunks of metal or bolts stuck to it, you got real problems somewhere!

Destin, I have a little challenge for you.

I have wondered about this particular occurrence all my life and it would be interesting to finally have an answer.

Some bar magnets (not all types) seem to change polarity when broken. Well at least half of the magnet does.

If you take a bar magnet it is polarized as such.

N----------S

When you break it in half it should polarize as such.

N-----S N-----S

But it doesn’t.

If it were polarized the way you would assume. The broken ends would be opposite polarity and be attracted to each other, but they repel each other.

For this to happen on end of the magnet has to switch polarity.
N-----S S-----N

Can you find an explanation for this?

Would this be a useful application for automobiles?  One aspect of the automobile design that is the biggest waste of energy (i.e. hindrance of fuel efficiency) is the start of the car from a dead stop.  You use all that energy to get the car moving only to apply the brakes and lose that forward momentum.  The ability to create a magnetic spring, such as the one shown in the video, could easily solve this problem.  By applying the brakes, you rotate the magnets to attract and slow the spinning of the wheels.  To start again, the releasing of the brake would turn the magnets in the opposite direct, causing them to repel each other and that energy could use to start the wheels spinning again; in essence, reducing the amount of gas needed to get the car moving.

You've had magnets like this (but not as detailed) on your refrigerator for YEARS! Those flat magnets that come on the phone book have alternating N/S/N/S on their faces. Put 2 of the same magnets back to back (black to black) and then pull them side to side along the plane. In one axis, they will just slide, but in the other, they will "hop" as a N passes over another N, and then attract again as the N passes over a S.

Refrigerator magnets use this idea of surface poles to help the magnet stick to the 'fridge.  I used refrigerator magnets and made a demonstration of a nut and bolt.  This allowed the nut to be turned and run up and down the bolt.  If you wanted you could "strip" the magnetic threads and pull the nut without turning it.  I also imposed a single pith thread over a double pitch thread on the bolt so two nuts would travel up and down at different rates.  And another bolt that had a left hand and a right hand thread.  I also have a patent on a magnetic numerical display used for counting.  See patent # 6,295,416

It was so cool watching this video that my mind is racing to come up with ideas. And well, I saw another video you made earlier, about Gravity LIght. In there you described (with the help of the founder) how the different gears in the machine allow it produce light/electricity. The next thing I wondered was if it was how much energy was really being converted to electricity?

The potential energy of the bag(could be anything of course) minus the loss through the pulleys until we get to the gear mechanism. Now my basic idea is that if we can create strong magnets that lock (an extremely narrow space within which they repel and attract) very tightly, we could get rid of friction (heat sound etc), leading to greater efficiency of the gear box. Which means that the bag can come down at a much slower pace for the same revs of the turbine shaft.

Another possibility that I am currently trying think about is could we create better mag-lev rails.

Also, I often find that retracing your steps in the light of new discovery allows you to see things you did not see earlier and to see things differently from how you saw them before. Revisit some of your old ideas, it might give you a mind blowing application.

I'd be interested to see how this will advance generator technology.

I'd love to see how this is ultimately applied to integrated circuits and circuit boards (and yes, medical technology and miniaturization of gadgets). There's a common phenomenon in electricity whereby a small electrical field is created perpendicular to current flow. If integrated circuits are close enough, the respective magnetic fields can create electrical interference with each other. The gentleman from the company briefly mentioned this. It's called capacitive reactance.

If magnetic lines of interference can ultimately be controlled, it may have huge implications on electronics and medical gadgets. What comes to mind in medicine is MRI where RF interference can be a big problem. And/Or perhaps the magnetic field of the MRI could be contained in a smaller space and have huge safety advantages. Interesting stuff!

This is epic! I love it! Another example of how encoding information in material leads to emergent behaviour. If you think these magnets are cool you should investigate amino acids that make up proteins.
In the magnetic case you have a binary information: N or s. In the amino acid case you have twenty different amino acids with different properties. By putting together lots of amino acids into different sequences you get three dimensional structures that all interact in weird and wonderful ways! Just like the printed magnets.

This is how biology self assembles into living stuff!! You could make chains of these magnets and allow them to "fold up" into larger structures. Eg print out twenty or so different patterns onto a standard block that can connect to other standard blocks (the backbone). The variations in patterns will modify how the structure folds.
You want primary patterns which are strong and hold the chain together. And weaker patterns which modify the close range details. By switching the order if the library of twenty blocks you will create super structures with a wide range of properties!
The larger structures will face emergent properties of their own like proteins! Self building buildings; transformers.... Robots in disguise...
Each chain will, in general, have many configurations. Some will be more stable than others..... But you should be able to flip conformations very easily! You could use thus to make it easier to recycle stuff... Or remove components from OEM systems...
Open source the patterns! The library of building blocks you create will be like an instruction set for a microchip... Perform Assay and selection (genetic algorithms) to find useful alphabets....!

Good luck!

It's almose like HDD works, only in bigger with NdFeB magnets. The principle to have more than one pole on one side is not new, it is done since many years for small motors and generators. The big thing is that they can do it in rappid prototyping. Before that, they needed a special magnetising-setup for every new magnetisation-design.

The 'printed' attract/repel/locking 'designable' magnet manufacture is an extension of magnets fabricated using the Halbach array polarization technique. We're all familiar with Halbach array magnets - they are commonly called fridge magnets. Wiki has all the details. However, being able to use strong magnets and to design complex shapes on them is excellent.  I'm looking forward to all sorts of applications particularly in replacing mechanisms where springs and mechanical latches are currently used.

I play harmonica. In the harmonica world there are basically two main types of harmonicas, diatonics (blues harmonica) and chromatics (they have the button). There are a few other less common harps- tremolos, chord harps, etc.

There is one particularly neat harp though, made by Turboharp, that takes a stainless steel reeded harmonica from Seydel and puts a button on it- but instead of blocking the airflow in a chromatic the button pushes magnets closer to the reeds, which changes how quickly they swing (which changes their pitch). Right now it only works on the 'blow' reeds directly (I think the way the harmonica is laid out adding them to the draw reeds is going to be a challenge). Just changing the blow reeds lets you change the draw bends (draw bends can be bent between the pitch of the two reeds in the hole, and on hole 7 and up blow reeds a draw reeds switch which one is the higher of the two notes.)

The Turboharp is a clever piece of engineering that exploits the weird dynamics inside the harmonica by disrupting things with magnets. This might open other options. Can you print a magnet like this onto a bendable surface?

And that's just the harmonica stuff. You could do funky things with speakers if you could change how certain parts interacted with the energy running through it.

Or how about key locks, where not only does the key have to be the right shape for the lock, but the right parts of the key have to have the right polarity. (You could, I suppose, just have a blank cylinder with a pattern that physically repelled certain pistons in the lock. I think I saw something like this, but it was big and on a clunky scale. They say that with decent camera you can get a picture of someones' keys from 60 feet away with enough detail to make a copy. Adding a magnetic component (as opposed to an electronic component that doesn't work when the power is out) might be a neat way to go.

What is the ultimate resolution? It seems the finer the resolution the less you would have to move two circles to go from 'unlocked' to 'really locked'.

I had an idea for a puzzle a few years back- it was simple geometric shapes. Using a mix of diamagnetic, ferrous, and paramagnetic 'locks' put on the corners the idea was the shape would look easier to put back together but actually require you to line up the correct north/south/diamagnetic/ferrous latches to get it. I was running into problems with not having enough possible combinations. The ultimate goal was to have triangles that could interlock into a few different puzzles, (so sort of in the Rubik's Cube, Snake, Magic Triangle genre) but with tradable pieces. That was going to be the gimmick- the triangles would have cool pictures on them and you could swap them with friends to customize your puzzle.

(It wasn't so much a serious idea to take to market as an idea to see if I could solve it so I wouldn't be bored for a few days.) Still, it could work. There were a couple old card games, the one I remember is Don't Break the Pipes, where you laid out a network of pipes to run water from one place to another. The pipes were cards in your hand and brass wouldn't leak. You could put a leak on your opponents network and they couldn't advance until they had the right card to patch it (or a wrench?). You could design a card game with visceral feedback about what you could place where. Smart dominoes! Maybe even have a game where you had to build a 3d structure to reach to the central platform, but different pieces would stick to different pieces.

Then turn off the laser and let the surface cool down below its Curie point. This way you could probably have magnetic domains "frozen" in that specific direction.

I sit here trying to figure out how they print these magnets, when I should be getting ready for work. That's how much you've blown my mind this day.  Hats off to you, good sirs!The closest I can figure is that they are using a material with a very high coercivity. They heat the material (maybe with a laser), and while the material is close to its curie point they apply a magnetic field to the heated area, and allow it to cool. This imprints the magnetic field on the material. Once the material is cool again, the coercivity is high, and they can print neighbor regions then. The areas that are not hot enough are resistant to magnetic field changes and won't be affected by the "writing" of neighbor regions.  That's my best guess. Anyone else come up with a method of replicating this?

"printing" a magnetic pattern is not new, it has been around for a long, long while.  Your typical refrigerator sheet magnet has line patterns put in place by a permanent magnetic roller.  Your credit card has a magnetic pattern that was also printed (you can see it with the magnetic viewer film, the 3M green film shown on your video).  What is interesting about these machines is their ability to localize magnetize rare earth magnets which has incredibly high coercivity compared to the ferrite ceramic magnet of your refrigerator.  Good engineering, but not a new science. Very cool video.

Awwww man. I made polymags in 1986. We played around with them in the science museum office, but no obvious applications. Extremely weak though, made from little rubber-style ceramic magnet hexagons attached to plastic sheets. The cheap neo supermagnets came much later. PS: make your own crude version...

Get two loudspeaker donut ceramic magnets and some small pieces of Neo supermagnet. Use the neomagnet to write on the face of the donuts! Push the neo against the ceramic, repelling, and the neo will remagnetize the pole surface of the donut, changing N to S for example. If you can make corresponding opposite patterns on two ceramic magnets, then you can demonstrate the "locking" effect.

Probably need green magnetic film to do this right. Buy sheets of it on amazon.

This is a game changer. I've been saying for years that magnetism is a untapped future science and this proves it. Depending on the strength of the magnetism, I see this being used in any machine industry that has to bolt two plates together (railroad wheels, auto transmissions, setting up poles, etc.) Any type of assembly, really. Not to mention endless toy company ideas.

When I was a kid, I had a thought, an idea about a magnet that attracted itself to another magnet, but stopped a certain distance from it. My idea was that somehow different and similar magnetic fields could be combined for a sort of fixed levitation effect. I thought of taking a magnet like those little round ones that you had at the beginning, and cutting out little cylinders from it, then flipping them around and putting them back in, effectively making 'maxels'. Then you'd have some of the magnet pulling, and some pushing, and presumably one could do some complicated math to figure out how to fine-tune it.

My dad told me it wouldn't work, and that I should just leave the magnets on the fridge.

My teacher said the same thing about my idea for moving an asteroid into Earth orbit, and mining it for rare metals.

Oh well, it's still cool to see my crazy childhood sci-fi ideas coming to life.

I believe then, it would be feasible to print the magnets in such a way, that you could have perpetual motion.  The poles would constantly attract and repel, therefore never stop (once you initiated the action). Am I out in left field with this thought?

This actually made me excited. Like Destin, and probably most everyone else here I have always loved playing with magnets. I still continue to do so to this day. I have accidentally shattered dozens of neodymium magnets, and I don't plan on slowing down anytime soon. Seeing these printed magnets, something that I indeed have never seen before, really gave my imagination a startle. The idea of using a magnet housing and shaft by itself to work as a spring or shock absorbed is crazy by itself, but yeah it looks like it is only a few years away.

I hope those people at Polymagnet come up with a large myriad of applications and revolutionize a number of utilitarian technologies and are as successful as they should be, being pioneers in some crazy new and interesting field like this.

I do have a concern though. You would have to add secondary systems to use these as legit secure locks, because a deadbolt controlled primarily via magnetic force could be defeated with a torch or heat gun. So a traditional fastening system and or a bunch of security heat sinks to retain the field would be necessary, but certainly not all latches and locks would have to be that secure. They also might have a bit of a problem in high temp environments, like engines, but I don't doubt there is some way around those issues.

But not in your standard hybrid style Vehicle. We need to look at a company called protean electric. If you look at how they configure their in-line drivetrain motors you will see that they are miles ahead of so many other electric motor technologies for electric cars. Each of the electric motors runs independently for each wheel. So the regenerative breaking system is the same system as the power system. Any regenerative braking system will always cause some form of shudder due to the polls being opposed under load. This would have the potential to smooth over any breaking system. Next I'll try aluminum, which should work since it conducts flux. after that I'll try carbon fiber and copper infused epoxy.

Alternating sections with opposite polarities to give better holding strength is nothing new, use some magnetic viewing film on one of those flat fridge magnets and you will see that the sheet is a bunch of millimeter wide magnets glued side by side with alternating polarities. Ok, so I'm trying to make sense of this one. These guys are taking the neodymium discs prior to their being magnetized, and somehow their machine must be able to focus an incredibly narrow magnetic field onto the surface to achieve magnetization of only the selected 'maxel' area? I wonder if they are not careful in the patterns they choose if the magnets can be given massive internal stresses that make them want to break themselves apart. Another thing: I had always assumed that the polarity of a magnet really doesn't play much of a role in how strongly it attracts ferromagnetic materials, but I now see I've been looking at it narrow mindedly as with these magnets the polarity can manipulate the intensity of the field itself over a given distance. Shoot, you show magnets at 5:00 that have had their fields manipulated for a tight reach, I wonder if the opposite is possible? A pattern of magnetization that causes multiple fields to converge at a specific point in space that is above the magnet's surface, like the focal point of a parabola? My first thought is transmission of mechanical power. With a speed differential between two complimentary plates, there would still be some force transmitted. As the two faces come closer to the same speed, they would lock together like a direct lockup clutch resulting in a bery efficient power transfer. Much like a modern torque converter with a clutch, really, but with the potential to be more efficient without having to utilize a fliuid coupling. Then as soon as the vehicle begins slowing down beyond the force of engine braking (service brakes) the faces would be spun out of locking position allowing the engine to spin at a different speed compared to the transmission input.

Even as a replacement for just the clutch and leaving the torque converter in place...there's just so much potential here.

you can transform rotational movement into linear movement, not like in a steam powered train but along the axis of the wheel
Example: immagine 2 magnets with altrenating north and south poles regions, the axis is not uniform and the center of the disks where the axis goes isn't either.
On one side we have a disk that can rotate on the axis, this disk can be connected with a belt to some kind of engine that gives it rotational movement.
On the other side the axis is shaped like a + or similar, something that does nut allow rotational movement to the second disk, but only linear movement along the + shaped axis.
This way by rotating and alternating the poles on the first disk with enough speed, the second disk will be continuously attracted and repelled creating linear movement.

The only thing is, polarization doesn't last forever. when subjected to a field that goes against another, the poles slowly start to rotate to gain equilibrium. This happens over a very long time, though, so It should be fine for a while. This is why those "free energy" magnet contraptions aren't actually free. The electricity that is used to create the polarization is stored in the magnet, and using it decreases the alignment over time.

I want to report to you a strange thing that happened to a magnet I got in a geek type monthly box. it was a small magnet pellet with a handle made of glass with a metallic center/attach point. the whole thing came with a ferro fluid vial and you would get this funny weird spiky shape as you put the magnet close to the vial, but as we were messing with it a bit, something changed, and it's as if we tweaked the position of the field, because the handle is now attracted anywhere on the periphery of the pellet but repelled by the center , and of course the ferro fluid is also acting weird (spikes only on certain conditions now etc.)
I searched the net to understand how did we change the behavior of the magnet, with no conclusive results. if you are interested please contact me and I'll give you additional info, I can even send you the magnet if you want. or if it's a fairly common thing, please direct my search so I can understand it better. Thanks Destin.

I think everyone in this video was underestimating the value of the magnetic springs. You're effectively creating a frictionless spring. That could result in some huge discoveries in efficiency or untapped potential in things like car engines. Instead of physical springs controlling the valves, one of these magnets could be used instead.

What's also interesting is you can manipulate these printed mechanisms using other larger magnets. So for example if you needed to unlatch that lock, you might be able to use a bigger and more powerful spring to overwhelm the original magnetic forces.

If these polymagnets can be electromagnetically controlled, this could be the next miracle material for machinery.
